div.stage: [The accused entered court] --- Upon commencing at 9.32 a.m.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Good morning to everyone in and around this courtroom. Madam Registrar, would you please call the case.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Good morning, Your Honours. This is the case IT-09-92-T, The Prosecutor versus Ratko Mladic.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Madam Registrar. If there are no preliminaries, then could the witness be escorted into the courtroom.

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Groome.

sp.speaker: MR. GROOME:
sp.p: If I could briefly make use of this time. It seems that we may have some unused hearing time tomorrow, so with a view towards trying to make full use of the time, the Chamber had asked me to address the Chamber with respect to 92 bis witnesses on Monday. I would be prepared to do that tomorrow. There are also some -- a proposition I'd like to make with respect to some of the documentary evidence with Monday's witness, perhaps we could discuss that, and Ms. Bibles would also like to address some of the concerns raised by Mr. Ivetic with respect to the late notice of exhibits. So if we could tentatively keep that in our minds for possible matter to be discussed tomorrow. Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. If we have time left tomorrow, that could certainly be used for this purpose.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Vulliamy.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Good morning, Your Honour. Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. I'd like to remind you that you're still bound by the solemn declaration you've given at the beginning of your testimony yesterday.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Absolutely, sir.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Lukic, are ready to continue -- Mr. Ivetic, are you ready to continue your cross-examination.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: I am, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Good morning, Mr. Vulliamy.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Good morning, sir.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Yesterday we left off with 65 ter number 17992, and I'd like to go back to that.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: And it will be page in the English in e-court at the top of the page, and page in the Serbian in the middle of the page.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, again, sir, for your information, this your article "Shame of Camp Omarska" that was published 7th of August, 1992.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: And again, it's page in the English on the top page in the Serbian in the middle.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, the selection I would like to ask you about begins as follows. It's actually the first full paragraph on that page: "Stories in Trnopolje, more freely told than in Omarska, are brimful of the squalid violence and black absurdity of civil war. There is a Sana, aged 13, who says: 'I was a fighter for the Muslims. They used to put us at the front when the fighting started. I was so scared that I ran away to the Serbian side of the village, to come here. I am still frightened, but I feel safer.'" First of all, sir, if you could help me out, is this the same 13-year-old that the ITN crew had filmed that talked about being -- used as used a human shield by the Muslim forces or is this another individual?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I'm not exactly sure, but I think it's the same one, yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Fair enough. Next, I'd like to go to the next paragraph in both versions of document, and the selection starts: "Then there was Igor, the Serbian soldier and guard whose uncle was killed last week and who says: 'I have my old school friends and my teacher in here [sic]

,' and then introduces his old pal Azmir, a professional footballer from behind the wire. 'I was taken here from Rizavanovci, after the fighting started,' says Azmir. 'There was some shooting from the Muslim side, then the police came and took the people away to clear the village of Muslims and to do the fighting.'" Do you remember these words, sir?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I do. I remember reporting them. I don't have a vivid recollection of the interview, but that is what the boy said.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Okay. Have you ever had occasion to hear or research about a military tactic whereby civilians are evacuated from a combat area before combat is engaged with enemy forces?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Generally or in this war?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Generally, sir.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Generally, yes, I'm sure it happens.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I'm not aware of that many occasions on which civilians were cleared during this part of the territory before they were attacked.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Would you agree with me that your information at the time was that Trnopolje centre was populated by civilians mainly, that is to say, persons that were believed not to have taken part in the armed uprising?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: My impression was that both Trnopolje and Omarska were populated by civilians and people who had not taken part in the fighting, contrary to what we'd been told.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, again, we'll get to Omarska. I'm asking question, and I want answers to the questions I'd ask you, sir. So I would ask you to focus your answers and we'd get through this a lot quicker.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Vulliamy, if at the end you feel that by just limiting yourself to the answer -- the question as put to you that something important would have been lost, then, please, you'll always have an opportunity at the end of your testimony to address whatever matter in this context.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: I'm very grateful to Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please proceed, Mr. Ivetic.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Am I correct that you were told by the Serb authorities in Prijedor that Omarska for those persons who were suspected of having taken part in crimes or in being combatants and thus needed to be investigated and screened out from normal civilians?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. And there was a briefing in Omarska about various categories of prisoners, and we had also been guaranteed by Dr. Karadzic that there were no camps for civilians.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You've mentioned the -- you've mentioned the briefing. I'm not sure if we're going to get this. Let me ask you this way: Am I correct that persons found to be not involved in the military uprising were transferred from Omarska to Trnopolje, while those who were found to have committed crimes as part of the military uprising were sent to Manjaca?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It was quite a complicated series of categories on which we were being briefed. To the best of my recollection, that was the idea or one of the versions that was given, that, yes, those who were found to have taken up arms would go to Manjaca as prisoners of war, and those who had not would be taken to Trnopolje. That did not accord with various other briefings in which I was told that people in Omarska were themselves prisoners of war, according to another account, but I think I've testified today -- sorry, yesterday, that there was nothing in -- at the time to indicate that the people in Omarska had been in any way combatants, and if I am permitted to talk about what has been found out subsequently, I now know them not have been.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Well, sir, I'd like to limit your testimony to what you eye-witnessed, what you objectively saw. I don't want to talk about matters that you've researched and that you --

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Especially research that I have not been provided. That would be unfair, sir. Now, let's just finish up with Trnopolje and then move to Omarska.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: At this time, Your Honours, I'd like to play the footage from the -- from yesterday, the item that we had wanted to -- delayed for today to have a transcript. We have prepared a transcript and that has been -- the process of it started to put it into e-court, but of course documents cannot get into e-court within the time-period that we have this morning to try and get it in, so I've distributed hard copies, I believe, to all the booths and to opposing counsel, and I believe Madam Registrar has copies for the Judges, if that's accurate. And then with Your Honours's indulgence, I can play the first clip one time through and then play it again as per the procedure that we've now introduced into these proceedings.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Meanwhile, Mr. Ivetic, if you want the witness to limit himself to what he saw, then put questions and ask him what he saw instead of asking: Am I correct that persons found to be not involved...? You are not asking for any personal observation of the witness, and then later to say that it's unfair that he does seems not to be the best practice.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: I apologise. I did misspeak. I thought we were still talking about what had been told by the Prijedor officials as was --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: No, read what your question was.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: May I proceed with the video?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please. If it is with text, we play it twice, yes.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: And now, Your Honours, for the second time.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Sorry, Mr. Ivetic. That last speaker, I don't see his speech on the transcript?

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: It should be -- I apologise, Your Honours. I don't have a copy of the transcript in front of me, but it should have translated the entire --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We'll carefully look at it and listen to it in the second round.

div.stage: [Video-clip played] "The two film crews visiting a humanitarian refugee centre in the village of Trnopolje, some to kilometres away from Omarska. The centre was mainly used by people in transit. They were trying to get away from the fighting and needed a place to stay during their travels. Our reporter, Mr. Bozanic, talked to some of these people who had escaped the war zone."

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: "[VOICEOVER]

: "Serbo-Croat 1st Speaker: First came those that didn't fight, that didn't ever fight. What do we have to fight for. "Serbo-Croat 1st Speaker: As soon as the shells started falling, we had to come. "Serbo-Croat Reporter: And what do you expect now? "Serbo-Croat 1st Speaker: That all the big shots step aside so they can live together again. "Serbo-Croat Reporter: What kind of status do you have here. Can you move ... are you free to move around? "Serbo-Croat 2nd Speaker: We can go and gather things and food from the neighbouring villages. "Serbo-Croat 3rd Speaker: They let us go ... to the villages. "Serbo-Croat 4th Speaker: I was lucky. I came with small kids. And I came with them from there, through the field. Nobody mistreated us. Nobody touched us. I was for 15 days in my village. My relatives were picked up and many of them have already reached Zagreb. Whoever had relatives, the majority would go to create Croatia."

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The interpreter notes that the sound quality is so poor that it is difficult to hear everything properly.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: French translation is finished. Please proceed, Mr. Ivetic.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honours. And I do note that the sound quality was low. It took us multiple times of listening through the tape to try and compile the transcript, and I believe there are still some portions that we could not fully make out.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, first of all, am I correct that this individual, this reporter in here is one of the gentlemen that was accompanying the ITN crew and yourself with the Serb TV crew upon the visit to Trnopolje?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I'm not absolutely certain, but you introduced it yesterday, I think, as the footage having been shot by the crew which was part of our escort, some but not all of whom were in fatigues. But it's a little confusing -- a bit difficult to answer your question, because I notice that the compilation, the copyright, is dated 2000 to 2008, which is several years after the event, by emperorsclothes.com, and I've never heard of them. So I'm not exactly sure what's shot when and what's compiled when by who, but obviously this is put together in 2000 and 2008. But I -- the footage, originally, would have been shot by the Bosnian Serb crew, I think.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Okay. And am I correct that this particular scene that we saw, this was the part of Trnopolje that was not fenced in where people could move in and out?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think it was one of the parts of the camp around the buildings where people were permitted to go and scavenge for food, yes. It wasn't the bit in which they were interned within that compound by the fence that we saw yesterday. There were various parts of the camp for different reason, as I've tried to explain.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And yesterday we talked about the comments of Dr. Stakic relating to the -- prior to you visiting Trnopolje. It would appear that these people here in Trnopolje were saying some of the same things as Dr. Stakic, would you not agree?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I've tried to help the Court with this notion of Trnopolje as a confused and confusing place. These people in -- in the montage, posthumously, as I gather from the dates on it, put together - shot by the Bosnian Serb crew, do indeed cite people who appear to say some of the things that accord with what Mr. Stakic was saying, though I noticed that the man said he was in flight from shelling when he arrived and that accords, I think, perhaps with what I've heard from other people, there and since who have fled villages under shell fire. But in response to your question, given that this was put together in 2000, I think that to describe Trnopolje as a humanitarian centre after what I had gleaned that day and what we were given -- what we were actually given that day in the photographs showing emaciated torsos and people beaten black and blue, and they were given to us on the day and, indeed, before this Tribunal by the year 2008 or 2000. But that is --

sp.speaker: MR. LUKIC:
sp.p: If can interrupt you, sir.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, if I could finish.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Well, I want to ask about this: You said people. Wasn't there one photograph of one person that you received?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. There were more than one -- one person that gave us the film, but there are more than one person in the photographs.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I don't remember that from your testimony. We'll check. Now please put your answer.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: My answer is that --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: [Overlapping speakers]
... Ms. Bibles.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honours. Your Honours, although it's somewhat innocuous, the practice of commenting on a witness's evidence we would object to. We would simply ask for the standard question/answer format.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Ivetic, what you remember and what you'll check is for you to decide and not to be communicated with the witness. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Fair enough. If we can go to the next clip, which is from minutes and 46 seconds to minutes and 34 seconds of part two of the original video. And Your Honours, again, this is a section that is subtitled but for which we did, apart from the subtitles, prepare a -- the transcript which starts on page of the hard copy that was handed out, so I will play it through once through, beginning now.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Second time through.

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: "[VOICEOVER]

: Most of the people came here voluntarily, probably for food, and very often there was the issue of evacuation. You're from a big international organisation. Did you receive assistance? "No. Only for refugees from Croatia. "But since the fighting in Prijedor, people have the status of displaced persons, not that of refugees."

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: The interpreter again notes that the sound quality is very poor and it is difficult to verify the accuracy of the translation provided.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: That is on the record that the sound quality is very poor and difficult to verify. We'll see how to deal with that. Please proceed, Mr. Ivetic.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Mr. Vulliamy, do you recall this lady from the Yugoslav Red Cross being at Trnopolje when you visited the ITN crew?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Not vividly, but I do recall her being there. She is from the Yugoslav, not the International Red Cross. Her point about -- that's why I noted her point about the international aid. The International Red Cross had been refused admission into Trnopolje.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you have knowledge of humanitarian aid sent from Serbia for these displaced persons at Trnopolje?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Your Honours, no, I didn't. We -- there was a medical centre in Trnopolje which I've described in previous testimony. Won't take your time with that now. But just to answer the question: The only aid, if that's the right word, that I was aware of at the time on the day was that which Dr. Merdzanic, who we saw in the video extract, and a lady vet helping him had managed to scavenge from houses from which people had fled in the village. The Yugoslav Red Cross was there, I do recall them and interviewed them. Indeed, they gave Omarska a clear bill of health and were happy with the state of affairs at Trnopolje.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Now, the question was focussing on humanitarian aid sent from Serbia, so the simple answer to that is that you are not aware of that?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Unless some of the material they'd scavenged from these houses had come from Serbia, but I wasn't aware of the Yugoslav Red Cross providing any. Only that I've just described.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, but the question was not limited to the Red Cross. I think the initial question was humanitarian aid sent from Serbia by --

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Whoever. Yes, sorry, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The last excerpt that I'd like to play is from the minutes and 49 seconds to minutes and 40 seconds of part and is the first 59 seconds of part 3.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: And this section, Your Honours, is not subtitled. However, it is almost entirely in English except for a few utterances at the end. The transcript -- draft transcript that we have prepared last night from pages -- the middle of page onward tries to incorporate both the transcript of the spoken English and a translation of the spoken B/C/S, or Serbo-Croat, and so I will now play it through the first time.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: And now the second viewing.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. The quality seems to me already very poor, although --

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: It is, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: -- what I read is -- at least comes close to the gist, apparently, of what is discussed, although I had great difficulties following it even in English. But let us play it, and with all the shortcomings and with all the reserves we may have as to the quality of the material of the transcript, and, therefore, necessarily, not because of our interpreters but of the translation as well.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Absolutely.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please proceed.
