"[Indiscernible] take you back and -- "No, it is very fine "You're fine? "Very fine. "How did you come here? You're a fighter? "With a bus. With a bus. "Are you a fighter? "No. "They came to your house and took you? "Yes. "Do you feel safe here? "I think it is very safe. But it's -- it's very hot. Other things that [indiscernible]. "But this man is very thin. "Yes, very thin, but, I think [indiscernible] -- is thin, all the people is not the same. Not the same. No, no, I think this person is a refugee. Not a prisoner. "[Indiscernible]. "I think it depends on the legal government. "Depends on the legal government. You cannot leave -- you cannot leave here? "No, not now. Not now. "Where are the women and children? "Gone. "Women and children in the house [indiscernible]. "Where are the women and children? "Gone. "The women in the house, other [indiscernible]. "What does this exist? "Yes. "[Indiscernible]. "It's a refugee camp "Where do you want to go? "Go home."

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: "[VOICEOVER]
: A voice coming from the background says: Tell them there's no food. A voice from the background: Look at the sight of him."

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: Sir, am I correct that you would have been located with Ms. Marshall, who is the female reporter that was in this clip?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. You can see me in the picture.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I wasn't sure.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And does this video-clip accurately depict what you recall this person in the blue overalls and those around him saying during this segment?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I didn't hear all of this. These are the untransmitted ITN rushes, they must be, as disclosed in, I think, the Tadic case. I recognise them.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Your Honours, before we move on to the next topic, can we seek to admit this video 1D259 into evidence with the caveat it should be marked for identification until the draft transcript is uploaded into e-court.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ms. Bibles.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honour, we do not oppose marking this video for identification purposes. We would, however, reserve our position on all materials from this web site until we've had an opportunity obtain a little more foundation.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Whether it comes from that web site or whether just the web site is mentioned in the material is not clear to me yet. Mr. Ivetic, any further information about that?

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: It's -- well, it's my understanding that that's the web site that originally re-hosted this video in 2000. The -- it's dubbed in English, and my understanding is that there's B/C/S underlying the English and that this was broadcast on some TV in the region in the Balkans, probably closer to the events, but I've not been able to verify that yet and I will provide the Chamber with information as soon as I find more. Mr. Vulliamy has now said that this appears to be outtakes that would have been part of the Tadic proceedings. I do not know that. If that is the case, I will track it down via that means as well.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: The exhibit will be MFI'd. Madam Registrar.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Document 1D259 becomes Exhibit D44, marked for identification, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. And keeps that status and we expect more information from the Defence.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: Sir, I would now like to switch gears and focus on Omarska and the time that you spent there as a fact witness. First of all, I would like to call up 65 ter number 17992 again. That would again be you are article written a couple of days after -- or published, I should say, a couple of days after you were at Omarska. And this time, I would like to look at the second page in English at something that Mr. Sebakoudin Anezovic [phoen]
is reported to have told you in the article.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: It's in the middle of the page in English. And I believe it's also page of the B/C/S. 17992 is the 65 ter number. There we go.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And there I think we can see in the middle of the English towards the top, the section that starts: "I was in the defence force - but not caught in a fight. I tried to get to Trnopolje transit camp (a civilian camp) but the army caught me on the way and brought me here? "Sebakoudin, who shows no signs of beating, says, 'We are going investigated. Because I know that nothing can be hidden, I tell the truth and hope I will be okay. If I am guilty, then I'll have to face the consequences. I speak only of myself - personally, nobody touched me.'" And I think I may have had a missed end quote before "Sebakoudin says," -- before this section that says "Sebakoudin, who shows no sign of beating," and then it should be begin quotations for the remainder of it. Sir, do you recall this interview with this --

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I recall talking with this man. Yeah. He was presented by the guards on our way in.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: When he mentions being part of a defence force, did you take that to mean he was part of the Bosnian Muslim Territorial Defence or TO in Prijedor?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Could have been that. Could have been a policeman in the town.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: These words about Trnopolje transit camp, and especially the part "(a civilian camp)," are those your words or his?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They would be his.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: If we could stay on the same page I'd like to ask you about another person that was detained at Omarska -- or excuse me, another person that you'd -- ah, here it is. I apologise. First, before we get to the other person that was detained, I think I found the discussion that you'd mentioned about the categories and that's on the same page where there's a person talking and I'd like to start off by reading it. It goes: "Omarska, they tell us, is an investigative centre for men suspected of being in the Muslim irregular army. They were [sic]

rounded up or arrested, then screened to determine whether they are fighters or civilians." "Apart from their undernourishment and the humiliation of the drill, none of the 80 inmates we saw showed signs of violence or beating. "Those found to have prepared the rebellion go into category A, explains the police chief's spokesperson [sic]

Nada Balban. There have been 126. They are awaiting trial. "Those found to be fighters are category B and go eventually to a prisoner of war camp at Manjaca, to which the Red Cross has been admitted (and to which the Serbian military were eager to steer us, rather than Omarska), and then to a military court. 'There have been 1.290.'" Now, first, sir, I want to ask you about the phrase here that you use, that the military were eager to steer to you Manjaca. In fact, sir, as -- if I can refresh your recollection, isn't it Colonel Arsic of the military that suggested he could authorise your visit to Manjaca because it was under the jurisdiction of the army, but if you wanted to go to these other camps you would have to talk to the civilian authorities? Isn't that a far more fairer representation of what transpired?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I my recollection is certainly that at the municipal headquarters in Prijedor, Colonel Arsic had offered to take us to Manjaca, but we wanted to go to Omarska. And it is correct, as you say, and I've testified many times. He then handed us over to the other people in -- on his committee with regard to our trip to Omarska because, as you say -- as you quote, and you say, the Red Cross had visited Manjaca but not Omarska and that was our reason for wanting to go there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Fair enough. And now I'd like to ask you about an individual that you interviewed in Omarska. Do you recall the individual who had injuries to his face that reported that he had fallen and that the injuries were self-induced?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: If I may -- if I may fast forward, am I correct that you ran into this man years later when he was a member of the Bosnian Muslim army in the advance on Donji Vakuf?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I met him again by pure coincidence in 1995.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: And, Your Honours, for purposes of the record, this is the 16th September 2002 Stakic transcript, which is P199 in our case. This is transcript page 7941 of that day and is the 44th page in e-court where the witness talks about this. For the sake of efficiency, I will only ask a question as I do not think I need to have the quote up, but by all means, if -- if you think -- if the other side thinks we need to have the transcript up it can be put up.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now the question that I have that was unclear to me, sir, when you talked about meeting this man at or near Donji Vakuf, was he -- you mentioned a Bosnian military commander that was leading the advance on Donji Vakuf. Is that this individual or was he one of the other soldiers that was present?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. He was one of the other soldiers and he was able to tell me a bit more about the wound that he said had happened because he had fallen over. It wasn't at all he'd been very, very badly beaten and had been in the meantime treated for damage to his brain.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Okay. And you also say that he, I believe, in that section of the Stakic case, that he had regained weight. If I can try and have you go back in time to 1992 when the Prijedor officials were talking to your group, did they tell you of food shortages that were being caused by the war and that were being experienced by all persons in the region of Prijedor?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They did say some things about food shortages, but they were -- appeared to be not affecting everybody equally and did not explain the skeletal state of Mr. Velic, who is the man at question, when I met him in 2002.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Yesterday at the --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Not totally irrelevant in this context is that the words in the Stakic transcript are "he had put on an awful lot of weight by then." Not "he had gained weight." "He had put on an awful lot of weight." So therefore, if you do not show the relevant portion on the screen, please be very precise in your quotations.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: I apologise, Your Honour. I'm just trying to move along as quickly as possible to finish the witness in the time that I promised I would.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. But you can do that -- I mean, by misquoting, you are, as a matter of fact, we're losing time. And in preparing -- I'm not inviting you to have it on the screen. I am inviting you to carefully prepare and give a quote which is accurate, and that doesn't take any time. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: At yesterday's transcript, page 2594, lines 22 through 25, you seemed to dismiss the meal served at Omarska saying: "If that's what you could call it." Was that a comment on the quality of the meal?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Quality, quantity, and the apparent desperation with which they devoured it, which suggested that they had not seen much food, if any, for a while.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did anyone mention to you at that time that the kitchen that prepared food for Omarska prepared that same food to feed the Bosnian Serb police and the Bosnian Serb army in Prijedor municipality?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: If that's -- they didn't, no. And if they did, the guards were certainly getting food from some other source than the prisoners. Besides, they were in pretty good shape.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You have already mentioned Mr. Drljaca and Ms. Balaban [phoen]
from the police. Am I also correct that you were introduced to a Mr. Mijakic [phoen]
who was introduced to you as the commander of Omarska?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, we were introduced to Mr. Mijakic as the commander of the guards at the camp.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, Mr. Vulliamy, am I correct that Mr. Mijakic was also from the Prijedor police structures?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know which structure he was part of, actually. He was -- he had a beret on. He was wearing fatigues. I didn't and really don't know which structure he was. But he appeared to be answering to Mr. Drljaca, but I don't know exactly what chain of command he was under. I still don't.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: It's fair enough. Now I'd like to move to another topic. Am I correct that the Serb authorities gave you a list of suspected sites in Bosnia-Herzegovina where camps were said to be operated by the other sides to the conflict and meant for Serb detainees?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Such a list came from two sources. One was Dr. Karadzic himself and the other was from his deputy, Nikola Koljevic, during a rather strange tea we had after we found the camp, when he was sort of jeering at the west, generally, for having taken so long to find them and challenged us to look for the others on the other side.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And am I correct that one of the locations that was given to you was Dretelj?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, it was. And I took, as it were, that -- that the point that both these men were making seriously, and if I may just -- just go back to a question you asked me yesterday about sort of doing all the right things for my career and so on, I actually did not take up the opportunity to go and bask in our discoveries at Omarska and Trnopolje but went directly over to the other side, which took some time, in order to investigate Dretelj.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you say we went over to the other side. Dretelj was -- at the first time, you actually visited twice; is that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did. Once in 1992 on the occasion I'm talking about now, and then again in either late 1993 or early 1994. I think late 1993. There were different lots of prisoners in the camp each time.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The first time you went to Dretelj it was operated by the HOS paramilitary group under the auspices of the Croat -- Bosnian Croat forces and Serb detainees were being held there, is that accurate?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That is correct, yes, including women Serbian detainees, and we revealed the atrocity of that.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And the second time you visited, it was now no longer the HOS but other Bosnian Croat forces holding Bosnian Muslim detainees, and that would have been the time in 1993?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Correct. It was then transferred under the authority of the HVO, the Bosnian Croat army, and the inmates were, for the most part anyway, Bosnian Muslims.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: For the first part of my question here, I'd like to focus on the first visit that you had, I believe, around 15 August 1992, give or take a few days.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Correct. It's mid-August 1992, yes. It's immediately after we found the camps, given the time it took to go round the very long way to get there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Am I correct that you first had to go and see Mr. Mate Boban, leader of the Bosnian Croat faction, in his office in Grude?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I'd like to direct your attention to 1D00240.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Your Honours, there is the transcript of the witness's testimony in the Prlic proceedings before the ICTY. I'd like to call up page 31 in e-court. This is transcript page 1504 and this section starts at line 18 and goes on to the next page to line 10. And, sir, here I begin with the question that was posed to you: "Q.
Let me return to something that you said a few minutes [sic]

ago. This is reflected on page 26, lines 13 and 14 of the transcript. "You told us that this meeting was 'at his office in a town called Grude, a small town and quite a menacing place.' "Again, that's lines 13 and 14 of page 26 of today's transcript. Can you elaborate, sir, upon what you meant by 'a menacing place'? "A.

Well, I mean, both in -- both in this war and in previous wars I got used to places where I didn't feel comfortable. I didn't feel threatened. And let's put it that although there was no fighting, there was the odd rasp machine-gun fire into the sky. There were some very heavy lads around who weren't giving us very welcoming looks. The -- I didn't particularly like the fact that the portrait of Ante Pavelic, who was the Ustasha dictator in the Second World War, was in the windows of some of the shops, nor did I find it very tasteful that the U - a sort of capped U - of that movement had been painted on some of the walls. "I didn't feel that I -- that I was at risk, but it was an uncomfortable place to be, and it was an intimidating place and a heavily militarised one, although it was nowhere near any front line." Sir, do you recall this testimony from Prlic?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. And of course, I recall Grude as you've described.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And does it still accurately comport to your recollections of Grude?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And yesterday we talked about Mr. Stakic's speech where he talked of fears on the parts of Serbs due to their memories of World War II. Was the return of the Ustasha movement one the fears expressed by the Serb officials in Prijedor that you had met with one week prior to meeting with Mr. Boban?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they did talk about their experiences during the Second World War and we discussed this at length, actually, during an extraordinary conversation with Dr. Kovacevic who we met that day in 1992 who did make these recollections in 1996 when I talked to him, where he refined very interestingly, and very regretfully, some of the points he'd made in 1992.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: We'll get to that. Am I also correct that the list given to you by the Serb authorities included two locations at Tarcin and Konjic?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Konjic? Konjic I think was on the list. Tarcin, definitely, because I went to Tarcin to try and investigate that as well. It was a tunnel and I couldn't find anything when I went. It had either not existed or had been cleared by the time I got there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Would you be surprised to find out that right now in the state court of Bosnia-Herzegovina, they are in the middle of prosecuting eight Bosnian Muslims precisely in the case of Mustafa Djelenovic -- Djelilovic and others, case number S1 K 007914 KRI precisely for alleged crimes relating to not one but three detention camps in Tarcin that held Serbs, including in a silo, in a school, and in army barracks, torturing them continuously from 1992 through February 1996?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Would I be surprised? No. If it's -- if the trial is taking place, the trial is taking place. Why would I be surprised?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: But you found no evidence of that? You didn't see that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When I went there, I didn't see any of the tunnel that I endeavoured to -- to get to, and then having -- other things were happening, I -- perhaps I should have looked harder. We did Dretelj instead and we did pages to at Dretelj and the appalling conditions of the Serbian prisoners there. One couldn't go to all the camps and nor did we try to go to all the camps on the Bosnian Serb side. It would have been impossible.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: One last --

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But it doesn't surprise me, no, sir.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: One last question before, I think, we have the break: What about Konjic, did you ever have occasion to follow-up on or investigate Konjic?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, I didn't go to Konjic.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Your Honours, we're at the break now.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, we are at break. Mr. Ivetic, you made a great effort in giving the case number and all kind of details of that case. Are you going to do something with that or is it -- I mean, is it give the witness further leads to what he could look at or is it for the Chamber or?

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: It's to identify the proceedings to give as much information as possible to the witness to see if he was aware of that proceeding.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: And if -- I guess we could also get paperwork from that case, if Your Honours are interested.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Well, I'm not saying that. We'll take a break and we'll resume at ten minutes to 11.00, but not until after the witness has left the courtroom.

div.stage: [The witness stands down] --- Recess taken at 10.32 a.m. --- On resuming at 10.53 a.m.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Could the witness be escorted into the courtroom. Meanwhile, I use the opportunity to deal with a few matters. Scheduling for next week. The Prosecution has requested that the order of the first two witnesses scheduled for next week be reversed. The Defence does not oppose to this switch and the Chamber allows it. Could the Prosecution already start thinking about what it wants to do with the nine documents which were announced to be tendered as associated exhibits in the Rule 92 ter motion.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honours. I was going to address that at the end of redirect once I could see which documents have been used.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Then we'll wait for that.

div.stage: [The witness takes the stand] Mr. Ivetic, if you're ready you may proceed

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, the other location we mentioned in Bosnian Serbs where Serb authorities said that Serbs were being held by Muslim forces, Konjic: Do you agree with me that at the time you didn't know but now you know that place to be called by a different name, Celebici?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And was there a location called Lara in Split, Croatia, included on the list, if you know? And did you know anything about that location? Lara.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recall that one, no. I'm sorry. I'm sure if it was on the list, well and good. I don't remember it, I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Mladic, if there's any need to correct anything, it's not by speaking aloud. Especially because your microphone is not switched on so it would be lost for the record anyhow. Please take off your earphones say it at a low volume to one of the team members and then, of course, the Chamber appreciates your active participation and your contribution to the accuracy of the proceedings. Please proceed, Mr. Ivetic.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now, sir, I'd like to move to another topic that you've already alluded to, the fact that you returned to Prijedor to interview some of the Serb officials again. Am I correct that this was in February of 1996?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The officials you interviewed included Dr. Kovacevic and Dr. Stakic and, I believe, that the transcript from the Stakic proceedings that has been introduced into evidence goes into detail about your interviews of these individuals at that time. Am I correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The transcript of the Stakic case does -- I think, goes into -- is verbatim, the conversation with Dr. Stakic. As I recall, there is -- yes, and there is some consideration of the Kovacevic interview as well.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Am I correct that you neglected to introduce yourself by your real name to either Dr. Stakic or Dr. Kovacevic when you met and interviewed them in February of 1996?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I was afraid to do so.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you give them a fake name?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. I don't think I was asked for one. It -- I -- I just said I was from a newspaper.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Am I also correct that the meeting with Mr. Kovacevic was not recorded on tape, as the 1992 meetings had been?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, it was myself and another print reporter from the "New York Times."

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: As far as the meeting with Dr. Kovacevic is concerned, am I correct that Kovacevic drank homemade Slivovitz brandy throughout the meeting?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Throughout most of it, yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: How long did that meeting last?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I would say about between an hour and an hour and a quarter.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you --

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't recall exactly.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you drink alongside him or did you just symbolically take one sip but not keep pace with him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I certainly didn't keep pace with him. I had between a sip and a quarter of a glass.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Would you agree with me Kovacevic consumed seven to eight shots in that span of an hour or an hour and a quarter that included most of the bottle?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Something like that, yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And in the Stakic transcript, which, again, is Exhibit P199 in these proceedings, at page 228 in e-court, which is the transcript page T8125 from 17th September, 2002, you agreed that -- that Dr. Kovacevic was at least -- at least was definitely was not sober but that you would hesitate to call him intoxicated from the brandy at the time that you questioned him. Does that -- and we can wait for the page to come up, if you'd like to -- and it's at page 228. It should be near the bottom, I believe.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: It's at lines 19 and following "not sober" at line 22.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: Okay.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: He certainly wasn't sober. He was coherent, however. Admirably so. It was an extremely interesting conversation during which he was estimably candid. So he wasn't intoxicated inasmuch as he couldn't string a sentence together, but he certainly wasn't sober either.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You tasted the brandy. Was it potent?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That stuff usually is.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Am I correct that immediately after you completed the meetings and interviews in February of 1996 with Drs. Kovacevic and Stakic, at which time you did not advise them of your identity, you sent a CD with your notes of these meetings to a Mr. Keegan whom you knew very well at the Office of the Prosecutor of the ICTY Tribunal?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I sent a memorandum and some notes to Mr. Keegan, who I didn't know that well.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Well, I say you knew him because you met with him immediately prior to going to Prijedor to interview these individuals without giving your real name.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I met with him before I went. I can't remember how long before I went it was, but it wasn't immediately. And as I say, I didn't give my name to them because I was scared. I didn't have authority to be there and these men didn't have any reason to particularly like me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: If I could try to refresh your recollection, sir, we have been provided with a proofing -- excuse me, a statement, interview -- interview information sheet evidencing that you were interviewed at the ICTY 16th January 1996. Would that be immediately prior to going to Prijedor in February of 1996?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It's about a month before. Because I remember the day after the interviews we got back to Zagreb and it was St. Valentine's day, so that would put it a month before.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: In fact, Mr. Keegan and the Prosecution at that time not only wanted you to be a witness, they wanted you to be one of their key experts to establish the element of widespread and systematic crimes by Serbs including Drs. Kovacevic and Stakic; isn't that correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I didn't know exactly that they were after Kovacevic and Stakic. I was helping Mr. Keegan with the Tadic case.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And if I can focus on the chronology a little bit. Am I correct that you first met with the Office of the Prosecutor and with Mr. Keegan personally on 18th April, 1995, in Washington at your office?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I can't remember the date but it was in Washington, yeah.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And then you met with -- with the representatives of the ICTY again, as you mention, in January, about one month before going to Prijedor?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I think by then they were established here in The Hague. I'm not sure they were in -- in the previous year.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: At the time that you went to Prijedor in February of 1996 and interviewed these gentlemen, Drs. Stakic and Kovacevic, did you at any time identify yourself as someone who had met with the Prosecution for purposes of preparing to be a Prosecution witness or perhaps an expert witness?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, of course not. I was preparing an article for the newspaper. Which I wrote and was published.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did you at any time advise either of these men of their rights as suspects of Tribunal investigation, including the right to be represented by counsel or the right to refuse to answer any of your questions?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. A journalist doesn't do that and I didn't, no. I wanted to find out who they were and what they thought about all the things that we'd discussed that day when we I had met them and the things that had emerged since then about Omarska, Trnopolje, and Keraterm.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Would you consider your conduct in interviewing them in February 1996 under these conditions to be objective as a journalist?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I considered it to be necessary to -- to -- to getting the story in the extremity of the situation and given what, by then, I knew to be the record of extreme violence in the area and in those camps, in particular. I wasn't any --

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And I ask you again, would you consider your conduct in interviewing them in February of 1996, without giving your real name, without advising that you had been consulted twice to be an expert witness for the Office of the Prosecution, would you consider that conduct by yourself to be objective as a journalist?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I considered it the only way I was going to get them to talk about what had happened in 1992, the last time we'd met. I think if I'd declared myself as the person they met in 1992, I may have been arrested, I may well have been physically harmed or worse.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Would you consider your actions to have been undertaken neutrally or were you being partial at the time?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Well, we're splicing the words again here. I've already tried to explain to the Court that I think by this time I had followed up, to the best of my abilities, professionally the -- the -- the -- what -- that which had been hidden from us that day in August 1992. We knew an awful lot more by the time I went back to talk to these men. I thought it was certainly worthy and in the public interest to get their account of what they thought had been happening, and I think if I had declared who I was, I would have, A, not heard their accounts; and probably put myself in extreme danger.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Vulliamy, this is not really an answer to the question, I would think. The question was whether the actions undertaken, whether you considered them to be neutrally or you being partial at the time. And I did understand the question to say, well, if you first meet with the Prosecution and then go to someone you had interviewed earlier and further interview him, not telling that person that you had been consulted by the Prosecution, whether that makes you, in your own view, a partial person or whether you could still be neutral under those circumstances. Is that the question you had on your mind, Mr. Ivetic?

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Absolutely, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. So whether you had fear to, say, to present yourself under your own name is a different matter compared to this one.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: I'm sorry, Your Honour. Yes, I'll be more specific: Objective, yes; neutral, not necessarily, no.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: Did you consider that your interviews at this time were accomplishing a job that would be beneficial to the prosecution of these men before the Tribunal?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: If it was, that was a secondary consideration. I thought that what I was getting in those discussions was a -- it was extremely enlightening on the pressing matter of the worse violence in Europe for half a century, which is in the public interest.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: If we can please call up 65 ter number 1D00236 in e-court.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And while we're waiting for that, sir, this is a two-page information report from the Prosecution relating to another meeting you had with them, this time in 2001. Do you recall having a meeting with members of the staff of the Office of the Prosecutor of the Tribunal in 2001?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't remember this specific meeting, but I do recognise the name of the submitter as he is called at the top. He did come to interview me on a case, and I recognise some of the names below. Not all of them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Well, let me put to you the subject matter of the meeting and see if that refreshes your recollection of this meeting, and I'll start with the first and second paragraphs. "During a meeting with Mark Harmon Nicola Piecente and Ulrich Musselmeyer, I was briefed by Mark Harmon to meet with Edward Vullimay and hand in a copy of the Plavsic-Krajisnik indictment and to request that he reads the document and gives consideration to ways that the defendants could be linked alleged crimes. Harmon briefed me that Vulliamy may well have 'insider' knowledge that may assist us in showing the linkage. He also may be able to identify persons with a closer political perspective who that Vulliamy could contact on our behalf with a view to assisting us. "When I met with Vulliamy, I handed him a copy of the indictment and worked through the document with him. He discussed links that he could establish between Karadzic, Koljevic, Plavsic, down to Milutinovic and Arsic [sic]

of the Banja Luka and Prijedor military respectively, and down through Kovacevic, Stakic, Drljaca, and Mikic connected, he states, to Omarska and Trnopolje." And now, sir, I'll ask you: Does this refresh your recollection of a meeting that you had in 2001 with members of the Office of the Prosecutor of this Tribunal?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Can I see the date again --

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Absolutely.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: -- at the top, sir?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: It's at the top of the page.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It's very soon after 9/11 in New York on which I worked a lot. I don't recall the specific meeting, and you'd have to ask Mr. Tait-Harris about when and -- exactly when and where it was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: If I could --

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: But he did come to New York. I don't remember the other people being there. I don't remember this. I played no role in the -- the cases involving Mrs. Plavsic and Mr. Krajisnik. Insider knowledge is his term, not mine.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, did you -- did you offer them --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Could I first try to avoid any confusion. You said you don't remember the others being there. Now, if I read this document, and that's always the risk of looking at the document for the first time, it is that the author of the document met - that is, Jonathan Tait-Harris - met with Mark Harmon, Nicola Piecente, and Ulrich Musselmeyer, and that he subsequently - he, as far as I read here - alone met with Mr. Vulliamy where he gives no date for that meeting, so if it would have been the --

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: It would have been prior to this document, I would imagine.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. So, therefore it seems that perhaps having had only a glance to the document, you may have been confused as to with whom you are supposed to have met. Apart from where.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: And that's why I said in 2001, because I don't know the exact date when would you have met with this gentleman.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour. Yes. Rereading it, I see too that that's what's happening. Certainly I'm not having anything to do with The Hague at this time of 2001. At late in November. But, yes, I did meet with Mr. Tait-Harris in New York but not these other people regarding these cases or this matter.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Now, you say it was soon after 9/11. The date of this document is 5/11/2001. We always have to be very careful whether it's the 11th of May, or the 5th of November, but both not -- well, soon after 9/11 could be, if you make "soon" two months, but it could have also been before. I do not know what notation of dates is used. But I do understand that you now have a recollection of having met Mr. Tait-Harris?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes, I do. Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. And was that before or after 9/11, or don't you remember?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: I think it was before.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Which would then put this in --

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: In fact I'm pretty sure it was before.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Which would then put this in May rather than in November. At least --

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: I believe the American dates, yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: At least if the date of the document follows the meeting soon. I do not know how much time Mr. Tait-Harris may have taken to author this information report. Let's try by carefully reading every single letter to avoid misunderstandings.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: I think can I clarify things easily, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Well, if you can. Until now, at least, the witness was confused. That's for sure. About with whom he was supposed to have met.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Your Honours, I met with Mr. Tait-Harris in New York. I don't recall much about that meeting. And the others I didn't meet in the same room at all.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please proceed, Mr. Ivetic.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: Sir, with regard to this meeting that you say was in -- that you say was in May, you also had another meeting in November 2011 with the Office of the Prosecutor, didn't you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Do tell me? I don't know. November 2000 and?

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You testified in the Karadzic case at November 2011.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: You were briefed -- or you were proofed by the Office of the Prosecutor on 7th/11 -- 7th of November, 2011, does that refresh you recollection?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Almost certainly, yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now, if we can get back to this document, sir. Did you in fact provide advice or strategy to the Office of the Prosecutor --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Could I just stop you again. I think the name of the case which you mentioned in which the witness was proofed, I take it due to quick speaking, is missing in the transcript.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: I apologise. That would be the Karadzic proceedings.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: The Karadzic proceedings in --

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: 11th November, 2011. That would have been case number --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: It was 2011.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: 2011, correct. And the proofing was the 7th of November 2011.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. That's clear and it's also clear now in what context Mr. Vulliamy met.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: And now --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: [Overlapping speakers]
... there was confusion because apparently the witness understood it to be November 2000 but it's clear now that it was 2011. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: And now just to be absolutely clear, my questions are relating to the -- what we've established now as the May 11th meeting with Mr. Jonathan Tait-Harris. Did you in fact at that time provide advice on strategy to the Office of the Prosecution on how to prosecute Serb defendants?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I have been called in a number of trials and have testified to the Office of the Prosecutor what I know. I was not called in either the trial of Mrs. Plavsic or Mr. Krajisnik. This term "insider knowledge" is Mr. Tait-Harris's. I'm not aware that I had any or have any regarding Plavsic and Krajisnik, and if I had, they didn't see it as of any use to them because I wasn't called in those cases.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Well, let me ask you this, sir: Was there -- did the Office of the Prosecutor of the ICTY Tribunal have a case against Milutinovic, Arsic, or Mikic, or are those names that you suggested and provided advice on how to link them to crimes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know whether they this cases against those people, and I wasn't offering names for perspective indictments. Certainly not, sir. I work for a newspaper. Not for -- not for this Tribunal. I testified at this Tribunal.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So is it your testimony that Mr. Jonathan Tait-Harris is untruthful when he is saying here: "He discussed links that he could establish between Karadzic, Koljevic, Plavsic, down to Milutinovic and Arsic [sic]
of the Banja Luka and Prijedor military respectively, and down through Kovacevic, Stakic, Drljaca, and Mikic, connected, he states, to Omarska and Trnopolje."

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: I would like to intervene at this moment. Discussing links does not tell us who first mentioned the names. And you're putting to Mr. Vulliamy that Mr. Jonathan Tait-Harris is untruthful when he says he discussed links. The issue that was raised in the present examination of Mr. Vulliamy was: Did you give him the names or did he suggest the names to you. That's at least how I understood it. If I misunderstood, please clarify, Mr. Ivetic, together with the witness. But I think the suggestion that by saying "he discussed," that it also means that he came up with the names seems not to be automatic and logically compelling. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: Sir, prior to this time you had met with the Office of the Prosecutor twice, in April of 1995 and in January of 1996. At that time, they had discussed using you as an expert witness to prove widespread and systematic behaviour that could be linked to crimes. Is that accurate?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. I had been called as a witness, I think, in 1998 as well, so I'd met with them more than twice, between -- before the date of this memorandum. And I had been called in, I think, the case of Mr. Kovacevic which, to the best of my recollection, was 1998. And all these names would have been in my notebook, in my evidence, in the case of Dusko Tadic and the case of Mr. Kovacevic, Dr. Kovacevic, and perhaps, Your Honours, I could, as it were, resolve this matter by saying that's where the matters came from. They were in evidence. They were out there anyway and in my notes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: You are still with the last question, whereas Mr. Ivetic expected an answer to his next question: Whether, in those first meetings, April 1995, January 1996, whether the Office of the Prosecution had discussed with you to use you as an expert witness to prove widespread and systematic behaviour that could be linked to crimes. So it's the subject of the discussions in 1995/1996.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: I wasn't being asked to -- to discuss any -- any -- any links - his word - or any insider knowledge - his word. When I'm called by the Office of the Prosecution, I -- I give my evidence. I -- I don't understand, actually, what I'm being asked. I'm sorry.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes, then I'll repeat it to you. What Mr. Ivetic asked you is the following: When you met in April of 1995 and January 1996, and what was the subject matter of the discussion? Did that include a possible role for you as an expert witness? I leave it to that at the moment. Was that discussed?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: April 1995, if that's when it was, I can't remember. Oh, sorry. April 1995. Yes. It was to discuss my role as an expert witness in the Tadic case. Sorry. January 1996, likewise.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. And your expertise or your testimony would be about the widespread and systematic behaviour of -- that you had observed. Is that --

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes. I was asked to give an impression -- to give my overview of the entire war and the visit to the camps we have been discussing today and yesterday for -- to the Tadic Chamber.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Ivetic, please proceed.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: If we can return to this document that's still on the screen, sir. If I can ask you about, did the Office of the Prosecutor, as is reflected here, and I'll read -- well, let me read what Mr. Jonathan Tait-Harris has written so we are clear. In the first paragraph, which again is talking about his discussions or preparations prior to meeting with you, he says: "He also may be able to identify persons with a closer political perspective who that Vulliamy could contact on our behalf with a view to assisting us." Did the Office of the Prosecutor ask you to contact persons on their behalf to assist them in prosecuting Serbs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not that I recall. And if they did, I didn't. Because I wasn't in a position to contact people on their behalf, nor do I contact people on their behalf.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: If we could turn to the second page of this document, the second paragraph from the top. "With regards to forcible transfer, he recommended the use of his colleague Ian Traynor, of 'The Guardian' newspaper, who was well-informed on these matters." Did you provide or recommend the use of your colleague Ian Traynor of "The Guardian" newspaper for the Office of the Prosecutor to assist them to prosecute Serbs?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I may well have put them on to Ian, yes, because he did a lot of work on Kozarac and around that time and area, but he is not a Bosnian Serb. He is a colleague.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I don't know where the Bosnian Serb comes in from, sir, but I did not intend to imply that.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In the previous --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: It may be that it was misunderstood. The question was "did you," but I don't think whether you said "recognise," or "would you," maybe "did you recommend" --

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Recommend, I think.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: -- "the use of your colleague for the Office of the Prosecutor to assist to prosecute Serbs." That may have been misunderstood, that last portion, and may have caused the confusion. I think the witness has answered your question. The question, however, was composite. It was first a recommendation to use a person; and the second part of the question was, whether this was for the purpose of prosecuting Serbs. When you may have mentioned the name of your colleague, was it in the context of assisting the Prosecution to prepare Prosecutions of Serbs?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: It -- it would only have been that, yes. Maybe Mr. Traynor knew something I didn't. I can't actually remember which case we were discussing at this point with Mr. Tait-Harris.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. So when you gave that information, you thought that Mr. Traynor would have available information which might assist the Prosecution in their intended prosecutions, which you understood to be prosecution of Serbs at that time?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Probably, Your Honour, yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: [Overlapping speakers]

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: It may be that I was asked a question I didn't know the answer to or something like that.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Ivetic, I hope I assisted you.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: You have, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: If we can look at the last paragraph of this document which is already on the screen, the part that I wanted at the beginning. Mr. Jonathan Tait-Harris says: "The indictment was left with Vulliamy to allow him to give it further consideration. I asked him if he was able to provide any information concerning events in Sarajevo. He stated he could give general information available from a number of sources, such as random shelling, shootings, and the terrorising of the population." And that's the end of the quote I'd like to ask you about. Is it true that you offered information from many sources to the Office of the Prosecutor relating to Sarajevo?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: At least a number of sources.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: A number of sources.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: That's what you wanted to say.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: I apologise, yes.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Ah, so we're discussing Sarajevo at this point. I don't remember. It's best to ask Mr. Tait-Harris. I don't remember offering, sort of general sources. I see that I'm -- I -- I do give him an account of the Dobrinja water line shelling which I was a witness to, or at least the immediate aftermath of. But I don't recall giving him a list or -- or anything. I don't actually recall reading the indictment, I regret to say.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: Your Honours, I would tender this document, 65 ter number 1D00236 as an exhibit.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: No objection, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Madam Registrar.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Document 1D236 becomes Exhibit D45, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: D45 the document is admitted into evidence.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
Q.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you for your answers to my questions today.

sp.speaker: MR. IVETIC:
sp.p: I have no further questions for this witness, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Judge Moloto would have a question for you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Mr. Vulliamy, this morning you were asked questions about Trnopolje, and in one of your answers you said that it was a confused and confusing place and that you -- you -- there were areas which were not fenced in and there were others which were fenced in. What I would like to ask you is: Did you get an opportunity to visit all the parts of Trnopolje, including the fenced-in parts?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour. Yes. We did get the opportunity to tour the not -- not fenced in or partially fenced bits of the camp which are to the side where the buildings were essentially. And here was this -- and I'm sorry to put it in such vague language, this mixture of people with a mixture of reasons for being there, as I tried to establish. Some in flight, some corralled on buses. Others had come of their own accord. We did not get to be inside the fenced-in compound that you can see us filming through the fence into, if that's clear. There's this bit which has fencing on three sides, one of which is the barbed wire fence, with a wall at the back. That's the compound under guard and fenced off where the men had come that morning, we understood, from Keraterm. And we were not -- we were not permitted to go inside that area, but we were able to move and talk -- sometimes with the guards following us, sometimes not, in the area which was not fenced off or partially fenced off around the buildings. Does that help?

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Apart from those two parts, the partially fenced in and the one that is fenced in with barbed wire, were you aware of any other parts of the camp?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Oh. I mean, I didn't know then and I don't know now whether we saw, you know, every corner of it, to be honest.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: You know you haven't seen every corner of it. You have just told us you didn't have permission to get into the barbed wire, sir.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Oh, I see. No, no --

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: I'm asking you were you aware of any other part of the camp other than these two parts?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not at the time, no.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: At this now -- at this moment now, are you aware?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I think there were some rooms which had been mentioned during this work I've been doing for the new book where there were -- there were -- the places that have been mentioned where beatings and violations took place that I now know I did not visit in 1992, yes. I mean, I now know that we didn't see all -- all of the camp. I now know that we didn't see all of the camp that -- of the -- of the buildings. We didn't go into all the rooms, no.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Were you told anything about the purpose or purposes of those parts of the camp that you didn't visit?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Not at the time, no.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Were you given the purpose of those parts later?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I mean, I've gone over this in some detail and at length with many of the survivors and the people who were in the camp, the former internees.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: And what were the purposes of those other parts?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Some of the rooms I believe were used for the violation of girls and women, and there were rooms which were used for beating prisoners, including the one or two that we -- of which we were given the photographs on the day, and that is in -- in research that I've done during the 20 years since and others can testify who were actually in them if they are called in this trial. But I -- I have been told about places in Trnopolje where the violations and the beatings took place, but we didn't visit on the day, yes, since, but those are places that I did not know about when we went in.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: I thank you very much, Mr. Vulliamy.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Thank you, Judge.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: If you would just give me one second. Judge Fluegge has a question for you as well.

sp.speaker: JUDGE FLUEGGE:
sp.p: Mr. Vulliamy, we heard in the video and during your examination that some of the detainees were allowed to go to surrounding villages to get some food. Did anybody tell you that it was possible to leave the camp and to go somewhere else, despite these cases of gathering food in the surrounding villages; for instance, to go back to their homes or to other places in the former Yugoslavia or elsewhere.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour. Again, it's a bit -- it's -- it's quite a complicated answer, if you'll forgive me. Yes, I have spoken to people who were able to go foraging for food in the village of Trnopolje, most of the Muslims and very few Croats in that village having been forced to leave their homes, they were empty, and people could go back to -- to get food out of them. The doctor and vet that I've mentioned also went round the houses looking for medicines, basic aspirin, and so on. I've never met anyone who escaped from Trnopolje, as it were, who made the run, which I think you've asked about. But people were able to make, as it were, authorised visits back to their villages. I've interviewed at great length the vet on a number of occasions over the years, and she was able to, for instance, go back to Kozarac to pick up people who had been left after the shelling. She refers in particular to a blind old man, to a badly disabled old lady who actually was dead by the time they got there. So there is movement, but I've never met anyone who told me that they'd, as it were, left the camp, got away, gone home, and made it to Croatia on their own in safety.

sp.speaker: JUDGE FLUEGGE:
sp.p: Do I understand you correctly that those who were permitted to go to their homes or other places in the surrounding villages to get some food or medicine, that they all had to come back to Trnopolje?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It's my very strong impression that if they didn't they'd be in trouble of some kind. And it's also -- it was my impression on the day that we visited - and confirmed since - that it would have been extremely dangerous for them to have been moving unauthorised across country as a -- as a -- as it were, if you like, an ex-detainee of Trnopolje. That if they did, they would be likely to be apprehended and shot.

sp.speaker: JUDGE FLUEGGE:
sp.p: Thank you for your answers.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: I have a few questions for you as well. My first question is directly related to the questions Judge Fluegge asked you. In Trnopolje, as I understand, there were men, there were women, there were children. Now, those who were allowed to go back to their homes, could that be men, possibly a wife which was with them, if there were any families, as such, and the children, so that the whole of the family could return to their home to get food?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour. They were and would have been. Some food was able to be delivered as people arrived progressively while others had stayed at home, but again, just to -- to continue my answer to -- to Justice Fluegge. The -- I mean, there was a case which I've interviewed and reported of somebody who decided to go home, having been released from Keraterm to Trnopolje, went home to join his family in the house and they were all murdered. And so --

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: All of them. So, yes, but it was extremely dangerous of them -- for them to go home.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: My question was that were there families, that is, husband, wife, and children, detained in Trnopolje.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Oh yes. Yes.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: In their entirely -- in their entirety.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: If someone was allowed to go home, a man, for example, or a woman, would that person be allowed to take his wife or her husband and the children and to go home all together, or would one member of the family be allowed to go home or do you have any information about that?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know. But it's possible. And I don't know of any family that did, as it were, you know, leave in its entirety to go home.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: So you say you cannot confirm neither deny that this -- that whole families [Overlapping speakers]

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, no, I can't. No.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Yes. Then I have one question, also a follow-up question to the questions put to you by Judge Moloto. Judge Moloto asked you whether there were other parts, and then you described that you had had no access to the buildings, on the basis of adjudicated facts, this Chamber accepts without further evidence that among the buildings was a school, a two-storey school, and a building which was known as the -- as a -- the Dom, including a theatre, kind of a community building. When you said you had no access to rooms, are you referring to rooms in those buildings, or were they elsewhere?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know, sir. Your Honour, the -- the -- yes, I agree there were these two principal buildings, the school and the Dom cultural centre, community, whatever. I have since taken interviews with people about specific rooms in which women and girls were reportedly violated and there were reportedly beatings and killings. I did not get into wherever those rooms were. There was no sign, as I've testified and written, of any blood on walls or anything that I could see. Until we got the photographs that we were given that day. So it's difficult to answer the question exactly. There were clearly places that we didn't get to that I now know about, but we weren't, you know, hindered in our movements. And I don't know whether those rooms were in those two buildings or not.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Were there other buildings part of the Trnopolje camp?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know whether the rooms in which these episodes were said to have taken place were in those two buildings or in other buildings. There might have been places upstairs that we didn't get to. I didn't go up any stairs, for instance.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: If you say "other buildings," does that mean that other buildings were part of Trnopolje camp apart from the two main buildings, that there were more buildings which belonged to what you describe as the camp?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: So far as I know, to the best of my knowledge, the two buildings that you've described were the -- the main, as it were, built structures of the camp. But some -- or at least one of the violations that I've been told about took place, for instance, in an adjoining house. So one isn't quite sure where the frontier is, if you like. Sorry.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Finally, you have described the secluded part, fenced in the -- partly or not fenced in part. Was it clear where the boundaries of the camp were in general, and how would you know? If it's not fenced in...

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Right, yes, exactly. Thank you, Your Honour. Because with regard to the half of the camp that was fenced or partly fenced around the buildings, it was hard to judge where the boundary was. Particularly, as we've established, people could go scavenging for food, and there were violations, I now understand, in the house and adjoining. Very differently was that compound where the men had arrived from Keraterm. That was up against a wall on the side of the camp as we approached it from, I -- I'll work out -- I'll work out the direction if I think about a map. But that was a wall and three sides fencing, one of which was the barbed wire, and of that bit, of course, the compound was very clearly defined by the fencing and the guards around it and the wall.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you for those answers.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ms. Bibles, any need to re-examine the witness?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please do so. Let's have a look at the time. We are close to one hour. Would it be better to take the break now?

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: That would probably be the best idea, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Then I would request the usher to escort the witness out of the courtroom. We'd like to see you back in 20 minutes.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We take a break. And we resume at five minutes past midday.
sp.stage: --- Recess taken at 11.46 a.m. --- On resuming at 12.13 p.m.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Could the witness be escorted into the courtroom.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ms. Bibles, could you inform us as to the time you would need.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Your Honours, my best estimate is about maybe 30 minutes at the max.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Vulliamy, you'll now be re-examined by Ms. Bibles.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ms. Bibles, you may proceed.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Mr. Vulliamy, on cross-examination, you were asked a series of questions regarding an incident which occurred on the way to Omarska involving gun-fire. Do you recall that line of questions?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: And, Your Honours, I believe in the transcript it was pages 2621 through 2637.

sp.speaker: Q.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That they could put up the white flags and accept that they would have to hand over their properties, leave - and it turned out to be via Trnopolje for enforced deportation - or face consequences as had been meted to other places like Kozarac, that their houses would be flattened and that they would, like many others, be killed.

Q.
sp.p: You were asked about the description that you had given in your article of August 1992 describing that Trnopolje was not a concentration camp. Do you recall that line of questions?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, ma'am.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And in your answer, you partially explained that your opinion regarding this conclusion changed during the convoy to Travnik.

sp.speaker: MS. BIBLES:
sp.p: And Your Honours, this was yesterday at 2666 I believe at lines 18 to 19, although that's -- those are the numbers that I have.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Could you please tell us about the experience, what experience in the convoy changed your opinion about Trnopolje?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Although most of the people in the convoy had come from Sanski Most, there was a busload from Trnopolje, and the -- when we arrived Travnik, I realised the scale of what was happening and the regularity with which it was happening, that we were just one night among many, indeed every night, and the ferocity of what was happening because, as I ascertained quite soon afterwards, there had been a massacre four nights after our convoy on Mount Vlasic, known to this Tribunal as the Vlasic massacre. So in terms of Trnopolje, and its role, and the term "concentration camp" which I think I testified yesterday, I wanted to relate more to its South African origins than to the Third Reich, one realised -- at least I realised, directly, that the combination of the scale of these convoys of the enforced deportations, the regularity of them, every night, the numbers involved as were amassing in Travnik, something like 36.000 by the time we'd arrived and upon my return this got up into a -- into a much higher figures. Towards six figures. That Trnopolje was a kind of hub, a focal point for the internment of these people, civilians, family, children, old people - and there's no distinction here - for enforced deportations on convoys of the kind that I was on. I've testified in the evidence before about what it was like to be on that convoy. I don't need to take your time now with how terrifying it was. It was old people, children, someone in a wheelchair going over the rocks in the road, for instance, and it became quickly clear soon afterwards that Trnopolje was the focal point, the hub, the point of departure for the vast majority or -- not the vast but the majority of people in this systematic enforced deportation either that camp or directly, as in the case of those from Sanski Most, from their homes. So it was the experience of the convoy, the arrival in Travnik, subsequent visits to Travnik, and over the past 20 years very extensive interviews with people with who have shared that road that this was the purpose or one of the purposes of Trnopolje, as we also know many were killed, raped, or beaten while they were there.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And in the same vein, based on all of the experiences and work that you've just described, do you have an understanding as to what choices were available in 1992 to members of non- -- or to non-Serb leaders and professionals in those communities?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: We got a glimpse of this on the day, on the 5th of August, when it became clear that the leaders of opposition parties were in Omarska. We were introduced to the leader of the SDA, which was a pro-Muslim party. And I've -- it became quite quickly clear that members of, if I like, the intelligentsia, the political leadership, the local elite, were quickly earmarked for persecution, death, and actually there was a -- if the Court would permit me, there was a sort of a perverse pecking order in the violation of the women as I later established that, for instance, the camp commander Mijakic had to "have" a lady, who was the leader of the Croatian party. So the higher up the pecking order you were in the guards, the higher up the pecking order you, as it were, got the lady, for want of a better way of putting that. So, yes, there was a targeting of the intelligentsia, of the doctors, the educated people, without doubt.
