sp.p: And, again, sir, I asked you if you recognise the signature which is on top of the page.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: So if you can move on top of the page.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes. That's my signature.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
Q.
sp.p: Sir, I will now deal with a couple of corrections that you wanted to make to this statement.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: If we move to page of this statement - this is page -- page in both English and B/C/S.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And if you could look at the very first line of paragraph 17.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Maybe we can zoom in.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I understand there was a correction that you wanted to make with regard to the third person listed here. Can you tell us what the correction is?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It's Zoran's son, Goran. The correction, as far as the last name is concerned, is that the surname should be Deuric. Deuric. In fact, here it says "Djuric," so the correct surname is Deuric.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: So do I understand correctly that the full name, the correct one should read Goran Deuric, which was son of Zoran, right?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, that's correct.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Could we ask the witness to please spell the last name of this person.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
Q.
sp.p: Sir, could you please spell the last name of this person?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Goran, G-o-r-a-n.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: The last name, please. The family name.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: D-e-u-r-i-c, with a diacritic mark on it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: If we can now go to page 6. And zoom in on the very first line of paragraph 21.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, you wanted to make a correction also to the name mentioned here. Can you please tell us what that correction is?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. It had to do with the name, since there are two brothers Miljanici. There is Slavisa and I can't remember the other one. It only concerns -- the correction only concerns the name Miljanic.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Yes, in proofing you said the name was not Slavisa but Sinisa, correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, there were the two Miljanic brothers, so the correction only concerns the name.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Exactly. So -- in paragraph 21 you meant to refer to Sinisa Miljanic; right?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Okay. Taking into account these changes, are you satisfied that this statement is an accurate record of what happened and what you experienced as far as you can remember?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Can we now -- can I now ask the Court Officer to please display 65 ter 28377, and this is the supplemental statement signed on 11 October 1995.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, again, can I ask you to view the first page of the English document, in particular the signature at the bottom of the page, and please indicate whether you recognise the signature?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That's my signature.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Can we then go to the last page of the English document, page 4.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And again, I ask you whether you recognise the signature at the top of the page?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, that's my signature.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, are you satisfied that this supplemental statement is an accurate record of what happened and what you experienced as far as you remember?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. This supplemental statement relates to Gertbakovic [phoen]

sp.speaker: THE INTERPRETER:
sp.p: If the interpreter heard the name correctly.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
Q.
sp.p: Sir -- sir, can you please repeat? You said that the supplemental statement relates to ...

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To the Batkovici camp near Bijeljina.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you, sir. Now, subject to the corrections that we discussed for the previous statement, if the Chamber takes these two statements together, will it have a correct picture of your evidence?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And if you were asked today the same questions that you were asked during those interviews in 1994 and 1995, would you keep the same answers and provide the same information in substance?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, now that you have taken the solemn declaration, do you affirm that you have provided that information in accordance with the truth?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Your Honours, the Prosecution tenders the 65 ter 28376 and 28377, pursuant to Rule 92 ter as public exhibits.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Defence. I don't know yet who to address, but Mr. Stojanovic.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
We don't have any objections Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Madam Registrar, 28376 would become.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Becomes Exhibit P207, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: And is admitted into evidence. 28377.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Becomes Exhibit P208, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: And is admitted into evidence. You may proceed, Ms. D'Ascoli.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honours. Now, with the Chamber's permission I would briefly summarise Mr. Osmanovic evidence for the record and for the public.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: May I take it that you have explained to Mr. Osmanovic the purpose of reading out so that the public is aware of what is in his statement?

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Yes, I have, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Ibro Osmanovic is a Bosnian Muslim from Vlasenica who was detained during 1992 and 1993 in the Vlasenica police station, the Vlasenica municipality prison, Susica camp and Batkovic camp. He testifies about how the JNA took over the most vital departments in the town of Vlasenica on 23, 24 April 1992. On 22 May 1992, the witness was arrested and detained with other Muslim men in the police station at Vlasenica. This began a period of detention that lasted from May 1992 until July 1993 in different detention facilities. From the Vlasenica police station, the witness was transferred to the Vlasenica municipality prison, then the Susica camp, and finally Batkovic camp in Bijeljina where the witness ultimately remained until he was released in July 1993. While detained at Vlasenica municipality prison in June 1992, the witness was taken with other prisoners to the Muslim settlement of Drum, a suburb of Vlasenica, to bury bodies. He buried 22 bodies. Of all those men, all but one had single gun-shot wounds between their eyes. The witness provides evidence of beatings and mistreatments at Susica camp, a facility commanded by Dragan [realtime transcript read in error "Drago"]

Nikolic, and he also testifies about beatings and killings of the detainees held at Batkovic where the witness was moved at end of June 1992. And that concludes the summary of the evidence, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Thank you, Ms. D'Ascoli.

sp.speaker: JUDGE FLUEGGE:
sp.p: May I ask you for the clarity of the transcript. You mentioned a name in page 76, line 9. Is that properly recorded, Ms. D'Ascoli?

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: That should be Dragan Nikolic. I see that it is written Drago Nikolic.

sp.speaker: JUDGE FLUEGGE:
sp.p: Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: I also have a question to clarify. At page 75, line 19, you're saying that in Vlasenica police station the Vlasenica municipality prison Susica camp and Batkovici camp, and then you don't -- you mention the name of the army that brought the witness to those places but it's -- what was the name of the army?

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: I said that he testifies about how the JNA took over the most vital departments in town.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Thank you so much.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Thank you, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Mr. Osmanovic, now that I read the summary of your evidence, I'm going to ask you some questions to clarify or expand upon that evidence. First of all, do you know approximately how many inhabitants the town of Vlasenica had in 1992?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The municipality of Vlasenica had approximately 10.000 inhabitants.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What about the town, if you know?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The town of Vlasenica itself had between 4- and 5.000 inhabitants, if you include the suburbs.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, I understand from your statement, the 1994 one, at paragraph 10, that in April and May 1992, the Muslim population of Vlasenica was not allowed to move freely within the municipality or to leave it if they were not issued with specific passes for that purpose, and you also specify in the same paragraph that the passes to leave the town were issued by the crisis committee of Vlasenica. Now as you mention in that paragraph only the Muslim population, I take it that this procedure did not apply also to the -- did not apply to the Serb population; correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Muslim population moved around having obtained passes issued by the Crisis Staff of the Serbian municipality of Vlasenica. On the other hand, the Serbian population could move around freely without such passes.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Can I ask the Court Officer to call up 65 ter 02862, please.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, in the same paragraph 10 of your statement, you also tell that one time you were issued with one of such passes to go visit your brother. Now, can you please look at the original of this document. Did you have chance of reviewing it during proofing -- during preparation for your testimony?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you tell us what this document is.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: This is a pass in which passage to Zivinice is authorised. This is -- these are certificates that were issued for people who were leaving Vlasenica, and it was a pass or a certificate issued to Remzija Huric.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And is this pass similar to the one that was issued to you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. But where it says "we hereby authorise a trip to Zivinice," in my case it concerned a trip from Vlasenica to Bregovi where the family has a house, and I was enabled or allowed to go to Piskavice.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And whose signature was on the pass that was issued to you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Milenko Stanic signed it. And Matic signed on his behalf.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Objection.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Thank you.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And sir, what is the signature that you see on this pass; and is that similar or the same as the one that was on your pass?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Milenko Stanic signed, but Matic signed on his behalf in the same way that he signed for everyone else, and that was also the case for me.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Yes. So I take it, your pass, with regard to the signature, it looked exactly the same.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: I tender this document, 65 ter 02862 into evidence as a public exhibit, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: No objections. Madam Registrar.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Document 02862 becomes Exhibit P209, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: P209 is admitted into evidence.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
Q.
sp.p: Sir, I will now move to your detention in the municipality, in the Vlasenica municipality prison. At paragraph 28 of your 1994 statement, which is now P207, you describe how during your detention at the Vlasenica municipality prison you were taken to Drum to bury bodies and that you buried 22 bodies there. Can you tell me by whom you were taken to Drum?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: People from the police station in Vlasenica took us to Drum. People in uniform of Serbian ethnicity.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And this happened while you were detained at the Vlasenica municipality prison; correct?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And this was in June 1992. Do you remember more or less when in June?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: On the 2nd of June I was transferred to the municipal prison from the police station, so that was at the very beginning. It could have been on the 1st.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: With regard to the -- to the bodies that you buried, what type of clothing were they wearing?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were civilians.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Meaning you had -- meaning -- you mean that they had civilian clothes?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what was their age group, if you remember?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were between 20 and 60 years of age, roughly speaking.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And in the same paragraph, sir, you mention that you knew four of these 22 bodies; namely, Ekrim Jahic, his father Abdullah Jahic, Nedzad Odic, and Osmo Odic. Can you tell us what their ethnicity was?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They are people I knew, and they were of Muslim ethnicity.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know if also the other bodies were of the same ethnicity, Muslim?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. Because that settlement was inhabited exclusively by Muslims.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And do you know if these bodies were ever exhumed from there?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know whether they were moved from that place, but I do know that they were buried in the Sehiski [as interpreted]
cemetery in Vlasenica, after the armed conflict.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know the name of the cemetery where you buried them in -- in Drum? You mention -- you described it as being near the "boksit" stadium?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, behind the "boksit" stadium there's the Muslim cemetery Roblejakita [as interpreted]

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And is this a different cemetery from the previous one you mentioned, the Sehiski cemetery in Vlasenica? And I'm sorry for my pronunciation.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Sehici [as interpreted]

cemetery was created after the war. People who had been found in mass graves would be buried there as martyrs, people who had been killed in Vlasenica were subsequently buried there. In the Rakite cemetery, well, that cemetery was used to bury people as usual.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Okay. One last question with regard to this area of your testimony. Is the Dzamdzici village close to the village of Drum?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The Dzamdzici village is in the immediate vicinity just across the hill behind Drum village.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, I will now move to the Susica camp. You were transferred to Susica camp on 18 June 1992. And this is paragraph 31 of P207. Were you ever told why you were detained?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, never.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And later on at paragraph 32, you say that when you arrived into the hangar at Susica, there were about 500 to 550 people there. And you saw also people that you knew from -- from Vlasenica and surrounding villages. So of the men that you personally knew in Susica camp, were any of them involved, as far as you know, in any subversive or violent activities of any kind?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: As far as I know, no. Because there was no armed conflict in Vlasenica.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, at paragraph 37 of your 1994 statement, you describe how two detainees, Durmo Handzic and Asim Zildzic, two pensioners that you knew, they were taken out of the hangar by Dragan Nikolic on 22 June 1992. I want to show you a document with this regard.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Can the Court Officer please call up 65 ter 19197. And this is a report by prison warden Veljko Basic, dated the 22nd of June 1992 concerning the deaths of Durmo Handzic and Asim Zildzic at Susica camp.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, can you please look at the original of this document. Did you have a chance of reviewing it in the preparation for your testimony?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I saw it yesterday.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you please -- can you please have a look at the description of the cause of death for these two men and tell us if what you read in the document concerning the deaths of these two men corresponds to what you saw?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: It does not.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Did they die of heart attack, as this document states?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. They died because of beatings.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And was there -- was any medical examination ever done on the bodies of these two people at the camp, as far as you saw, because you were in the hangar?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Hadzic died right next to me. He was lying by my legs. And there was no examination carried out.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What about the second person?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Zildzic died during the night as soon as they brought him back after the beating.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Now, according also to what you saw happened after their deaths, can you tell us if you think that they could have been buried according to Muslim customs as this document says for both bodies?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Maybe they were only taken to the Muslim cemetery and buried there, but they certainly were not buried in accordance with Muslim rites.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And does of the date of this document, the 22nd of June, correspond to your recollection concerning when these two men died?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To the best of my recollection, the date tallies, the 22nd. However, this does not tally, what Veljko Basic said, that they were examined by a physician and buried in accordance with Muslim rites.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And do you know the person who signed this document?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Veljko Basic, retired policeman, acquitted by the Court of Bosnia and Herzegovina on account of his advanced age. He was commander of the camp in Susica.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Before you remove this exhibit from the screen, ma'am. Can we just establish from Mr. Osmanovic what is the family name of Asim?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Asim Zildzic.

sp.speaker: JUDGE MOLOTO:
sp.p: Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Your Honours, I tender 65 ter 19917 into evidence as a public exhibit.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Madam Registrar.

sp.speaker: THE REGISTRAR:
sp.p: Document 19917 becomes Exhibit P210, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: And is admitted into evidence. Please proceed.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
Q.
sp.p: Sir, in several paragraphs of your statement, for example paragraph 37, 39, 42, or 44 of P207, you describe episodes of men who were taken out of the hangar and beaten. On the basis of what you observed and experienced, would you say that beatings were frequent or not at Susica camp?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I can say that they were frequent. Some people were actually beaten every day.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And in your statement you also describe episodes of killings or of men who died after being taken out of the hangar and beaten. Can I ask you what was the ethnicity of all these detainees who were beaten and/or killed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They were Muslims.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, on the basis of what you observed and experienced in Susica camp, why do you think Bosnian Muslims were detained, beaten, and/or killed in Susica camp?

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Mr. Stojanovic.

sp.speaker: MR. STOJANOVIC:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
The witness would have to speculate in order to answer a question that was phrased this way.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Ms. D'Ascoli, could you please rephrase your question such that we know what -- on what facts the witness -- whatever opinion he may have formed, bases it.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
Q.
sp.p: Sir, during your detention at Susica camp, on the basis of the beatings or the killings or -- of what you saw was happening to Bosnian Muslim detainees, were you able to -- to form or to develop an idea or did you -- did you become aware of the reason why this was happening?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Quite simply all the beatings that happened to a certain group of people, all this torture that we suffered at the hands of our neighbours, until that day, no one could really figure this out. No one was guilty of anything. I lived in my own house. I was taken out of my house. And I was taken out there. The same thing happened to all my neighbours. Unfortunately, these people who were killed are no longer with us. They were accused of all sorts of things. One of them was accused of having manufactured knives, another one of smuggling. However, since he couldn't move about anywhere, I don't see how he could have smuggling. Also the one who was accused of making knives. When was he making these knives? So it was sufficient to pin something on someone and then they would experience what we experienced.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you already said that you were not given a reason for being detained. In so far as you know, were the people you knew there at the camp, were they ever told why they were detained?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No. On one occasion, they came and said that we would be exchanged for some detained Serbs who were allegedly grazing grass at the stadium in Tuzla. We received the same information in Batkovic once as well. However, we never found out what the actual reason for our detention was.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, I will now move to your detention in Batkovic. You were transferred there on the 30th of June, 1992, and you spent more than a year in this camp. Are you able to give an estimate for what you saw of how many persons approximately were detained there at Batkovic?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: When the Batkovic camp was established, the first group was brought in from Vlasenica on the 27th, the second one on the 28th, and I arrived in the third group on the 30th of the June. In Vlasenica there were between 500 and 550 of us. Four hundred had already arrived in Batkovic once I got there, because one group stayed on in Vlasenica. After that, people were brought in from the area of the municipality of Zvornik, from the area of the municipality of Brcko, from the area of the municipality of Lopare, Ugljevik, also from the area of the municipality of Rogatica. Today my estimate would be that at full capacity there were 3.500 of us in this camp.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, did you know many of the -- many people among the detainees there at Batkovic?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The people who arrived from Vlasenica, I knew them, 90 per cent of all of them.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: I now want to show you a document now.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: If the Court Officer, please, if they can call up P191.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: This is a photocopy of a list of persons detained at Batkovic stamped and certified on by the Bijeljina lower court as being identical to the original. And for each name, it lists last name, father's name, first name, date and place of birth, residence, date and time of arrival, the collection centre, and date and time of departure from the collection centre. Mr. Osmanovic, did you have a chance of reviewing in detail this document in preparation for your testimony?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And do you remember seeing on this document names that you recognised where -- of people detained with you at Batkovic?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: And if we can go to page 138 of the original of the document, please.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, sir, if you can look at entry number 21.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: That is my name and surname.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, and you also said that you recognised when you reviewed this rather long list, you were able to recognise many other persons listed in this document because they were detained there with you at Batkovic. I will just mention a couple of examples. For example, in your statement you mentioned a man called Fadil Halilhodzic at paragraphs 60 and 62 of P207. This man was singled out for beatings several times and he belonged to a group called the special prisoners, because they were often singled out for beatings. Do you remember seeing his name on this list?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: And for the record, Your Honours, this is entry number 38 on page of the original document, P191.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, further in your statement, paragraph 39 of P207, you also refer to someone by the name of Reuf Rasidagic who was beaten by Dragan Nikolic about five times over four or five days, and eventually begged Nikolic to kill him. Do you remember seeing his name on this list?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Rasidagic, Reuf. He was beaten up - he wasn't killed - by Dragan Nikolic at the Susica camp. He kicked him and he also hit him with his rifle, and he said to him, lie to me, telling me when you were last in a cinema. It's expensive to waste a bullet on you. Three marks per bullet. Tell me where your brother is. That was the reason why he beat him. And Reuf did arrive alive.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And you remember seeing also his name on this list?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, I remember that.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: And for the record, this is entry number 18 on page 151 of the original document, P191. Finally, if we can go to page 164 of the original, please. And if we can have a look at entry number 98.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, can you tell me if you recognise this name, entry 98?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Smajic Age Ejub from Bijeljina was beaten to death in Batkovic.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you, sir.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: I'm done with the document. Thanks.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Mr. Osmanovic, at paragraph 61 of P207, and then more extensively in your 1995 statement, which is P208, you tell about three detainees who appear to be willing participants in the beatings of other detainees and who would beat the other detainees with our without the presence of the guards. Now, my question is: How did the guards react when seeing such beatings from detainees on other detainees?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: They laughed and they approved of it.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And did they do anything about it?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: To stop them? No.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And, as far as you know, did any guard or other prison officials that you heard of suggest the possibility that anyone would be punished for participating in the beatings of other detainees?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: I don't know about any such thing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, and, again, with regard to the Batkovic camp, in several paragraphs of your statement, paragraphs 54 to 60, for example, you describe episodes of men who were taken out of the hangar and beaten; and also at paragraph 57 of the 1994 statement you also describe how an old man, Zulfo Hadziomerovic, died as a result of the beatings. Now, on the basis of what you saw, what you observed there at the camp, would you say that beatings were frequent or not, at the Batkovic camp?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Beatings were a daily thing. It was like a daily meal for a group of specials.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And what was the ethnicity of the detainees who were beaten and/or killed?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Muslims and Croats. Croats arrived once the Brcko camp had been closed down. Before that, there were only Muslims.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: What was the atmosphere there in the camp? Were you scared?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: An atmosphere of fear. Everyone was in fear for their own lives.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, I also want to ask you some questions about your family. Did you lose any family members in 1992/1993 after the takeover of Vlasenica town?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes. I lost three members of my family, my immediate family, and a total of 36 relatives from my extended family. I lost two brothers and a sister. The sister was 16 years old. She was burned to death. She was found at the location of Pelemis in the municipality of Sekovici. Only per cent of her mortal remains were found. My younger brother was found in the area of Kljestani of the municipality of Vlasenica. Three mass graves were discovered, and his head was found 25 kilometres away. As for my older brother, nothing has been found yet. I cannot find any trace whatsoever. So these are members of my very own family, from my very own home. Also my maternal uncle and his family, all of them are missing.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Can you tell me the name of your younger sister, the sister who was 16 years old?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ferida.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And can you clarify the circumstances of her death, if you know, what happened?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Mother was in camp and the sisters were sent to Cerska. She was a child and she got lost in the woods and was lost somewhere in the area of the Serb positions. Then she was returned to the Susica camp again. So the last traces led to Pelemis in the municipality of Sekovici. She was found this year. She was buried on the 24th -- or, rather, funeral services were held at the Muslim cemetery of martyrs. There were only per cent of her mortal remains were found, unfortunately. All the rest were burned. At this funeral service, most of the persons buried were young girls. None of them were even 18 years old.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: To clarify in the record, I see that her name is recorded as Ferid. Sir, can you repeat her first name?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Ferida.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: I think the witness said that only per cent of her remains were found. This in correction to page 90, line 23.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
Q.
sp.p: Can you also tell the Court the name of your younger brother and the name of your older brother?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Hajrudin, my younger brother, stayed on after me in Susica. He was born in 1967. My older brother, Hakija, was born in 1962. He was married to Dragica Sokic, a Serb woman. I last saw him when I was taken to Batkovic.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Where any -- because you mention your younger brother stayed in Susica after you. How many, if any, members of your family were held in detention in Susica camp?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Out of my family members, in addition to my brother Hakija who was married to a Serb woman and he had to report to the police station every 24 hours and he was detained in the police station, my entire family went through the Susica camp.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: And were the remains of your younger brother ever found?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yes, they were found. He was found at three locations.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Do you know the name of these locations or -- and did you participate in the identification process?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Kljestani and Kljestani 2. I took part in the identification process, and I also took part in the identification process for my sister, as we were looking for her.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Sir, do you think you can describe for the Court how the experience of losing so many members of your family and also being detained has affected you.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: The loss of family members is something that is the hardest of all. It is easy to look for someone that you're not related to, who is not your family. But to rummage through the bones of someone who was born by your very own mother, I mean, my sister was only 16 years old, and there are only four bones left of her. It's very hard to speak about something like that. It wasn't that hard for me to look for them. It was important for me to find them. And I managed to find two of them after all these years, and I don't know if I'll manage to find the third one.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: Thank you, Mr. Osmanovic.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: Your Honours, I see the time. I only have one aerial photo of the Susica camp that I would like to show to the witness. It is already in evidence, but I would like him to make some markings. But I can leave it for tomorrow. Besides that, my examination is -- will be concluded after that.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: I suggest that we do that tomorrow in order not to -- because it usually takes at least a couple of minutes and then ... Mr. Osmanovic, I'd like to instruct you that you should not speak with anyone or communicate with anyone about the testimony you have given today or the testimony you are still about to give tomorrow. Is that clear to you?

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Yes, Your Honour.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: Then we would like to see you back tomorrow morning at 9.30 in this same courtroom. You may follow the usher.

sp.speaker: THE WITNESS:
sp.p: [Interpretation]
Thank you very much.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: May I make one observation. I'm addressing you, Ms. D'Ascoli, but it happened to other counsel as well. Would you please carefully not only focus on your questions but also listen to the answers. To ask to a witness whether the remains of his younger brother were found, if, two minutes ago, he has told us that the head was found at 25 kilometres from the rest, is not something which avoids further painful experience. I do understand that if you want to know the location of the mass graves that you should inquire into which three places, but to ask him were the remains found, it may sound, in the ears of the witness, as you have not listened to his answer very well.

sp.speaker: MS. D'ASCOLI:
sp.p: I apologise, Your Honours.

sp.speaker: JUDGE ORIE:
sp.p: We adjourn for the day, and we resume tomorrow, Friday, the 21st of September, at 9.30 in the morning, in this same courtroom, I.
sp.stage: --- Whereupon the hearing adjourned at 2.16 p.m., to be reconvened on Friday, the 21st day of September, 2012, at 9.30 a.m.
